title: Future Perfect
description: Слушайте о действиях, которые будут завершены к определённому моменту.

tasks.audioText: The construction workers are making great progress. They will have finished the bridge by the end of December.
tasks.transcript: They will have finished the bridge by the end of December.

options.text: The bridge will be complete before January starts.
They are finishing the bridge right now.
They finished the bridge last December.
The bridge will never be completed.

tasks.explanation: 'Will have finished by the end of December' uses Future Perfect to indicate the bridge completion before a specific future deadline.

tasks.audioText: I started this book two weeks ago. By Friday, I will have read all five hundred pages.
tasks.transcript: By Friday, I will have read all five hundred pages.

options.text: I read the book last Friday.
I will finish reading the entire book before Friday ends.
I am reading right now.
I will start reading on Friday.

tasks.explanation: 'Will have read by Friday' means the reading will be completed before or on Friday — a future deadline with a completed action.

tasks.audioText: Our CEO announced a bold plan this morning. The company will have expanded to fifteen countries by 2030.
tasks.transcript: The company will have expanded to fifteen countries by 2030.

options.text: The company expanded to fifteen countries last year.
The company is expanding right now.
The company plans to be operating in fifteen countries before 2030 arrives.
The company will start expanding after 2030.

tasks.explanation: 'Will have expanded by 2030' uses Future Perfect to project a completed business goal before a specific year.

tasks.audioText: Sarah is training hard every day. She will have run over a thousand kilometres by the time the marathon season begins.
tasks.transcript: She will have run over a thousand kilometres by the time the marathon season begins.

options.text: She will accumulate more than a thousand kilometres of running before the season starts.
She ran a thousand kilometres last season.
She runs a thousand kilometres every week.
She will start running when the season begins.

tasks.explanation: 'Will have run by the time' combines Future Perfect with a time clause to show accumulated distance before a future event.

tasks.audioText: We moved into this flat three years ago. Next month, we will have lived here for exactly four years.
tasks.transcript: Next month, we will have lived here for exactly four years.

options.text: We lived here for four years in the past.
By next month, our time in this flat will total four years.
We are moving out next month.
We will move in next month.

tasks.explanation: 'Will have lived for four years' uses Future Perfect to describe a duration that reaches a milestone at a future point.

tasks.audioText: Dr. Chen is an incredible researcher. By the end of this year, she will have published over fifty scientific papers.
tasks.transcript: She will have published over fifty scientific papers by the end of this year.

options.text: She published fifty papers last year.
She is writing her first paper now.
Her total publications will exceed fifty before the year is over.
She stopped publishing papers recently.

tasks.explanation: 'Will have published by the end of this year' projects a cumulative achievement reaching completion at a future point.

tasks.audioText: The electricians started on Monday. They will have installed all the wiring before the painters arrive next week.
tasks.transcript: They will have installed all the wiring before the painters arrive next week.

options.text: The wiring installation will be done before the painting crew comes.
The painters will arrive before the wiring is installed.
The electricians and painters will work at the same time.
The wiring was installed last week already.

tasks.explanation: 'Will have installed before the painters arrive' uses Future Perfect to sequence two future events — wiring first, then painting.

tasks.audioText: My parents are celebrating a special anniversary soon. They will have been married for thirty years this June.
tasks.transcript: They will have been married for thirty years this June.

options.text: They got married thirty years after June.
Their marriage will reach its thirtieth anniversary in June.
They are getting married this June.
They divorced after thirty years.

tasks.explanation: 'Will have been married for thirty years' uses Future Perfect to mark a duration milestone at a specific future date.

tasks.audioText: The server migration is underway at our office. The IT team will have transferred all the data by midnight tonight.
tasks.transcript: The IT team will have transferred all the data by midnight tonight.

options.text: The data transfer will be complete before midnight.
The IT team transferred the data yesterday.
The team will start transferring data at midnight.
The data transfer was cancelled.

tasks.explanation: 'Will have transferred by midnight' sets a clear deadline for completion — all data moved before that time.

tasks.audioText: Elena is a dedicated volunteer at the shelter. By next spring, she will have donated over two hundred hours of her time.
tasks.transcript: She will have donated over two hundred hours of her time by next spring.

options.text: She donated two hundred hours last spring.
Her total volunteer hours will surpass two hundred before next spring.
She volunteers for exactly two hundred hours every spring.
She will begin volunteering next spring.

tasks.explanation: 'Will have donated by next spring' uses Future Perfect for an accumulated total reaching a milestone at a future time.

tasks.audioText: I need to hurry with my assignment. The professor will have collected all the essays before I get to class.
tasks.transcript: The professor will have collected all the essays before I get to class.

options.text: The professor will collect essays after I arrive.
I will arrive before the professor starts collecting.
All essays will already be gathered by the time I reach the classroom.
The professor never collects essays in class.

tasks.explanation: 'Will have collected before I get to class' shows the collection ending before the speaker's arrival — sequencing two future events.

tasks.audioText: The airline announced new routes today. By summer, they will have added direct flights to twelve new destinations.
tasks.transcript: They will have added direct flights to twelve new destinations by summer.

options.text: Twelve new flight routes will be operational before the summer season.
They added twelve routes last summer.
They are cancelling twelve routes this summer.
They will begin planning new routes in summer.

tasks.explanation: 'Will have added by summer' projects a completed expansion of routes before the summer deadline.

tasks.audioText: Our neighbours are renovating their kitchen. They will have spent over twenty thousand dollars on it by the time it is done.
tasks.transcript: They will have spent over twenty thousand dollars on it by the time it is done.

options.text: The total cost will exceed twenty thousand dollars when the renovation finishes.
They spent twenty thousand dollars last year.
They are saving twenty thousand dollars for the future.
The renovation costs nothing.

tasks.explanation: 'Will have spent by the time it is done' combines Future Perfect with a time clause to project the total cost at completion.

tasks.audioText: The patient is recovering well after the surgery. The doctors say he will have fully recovered by the end of the month.
tasks.transcript: He will have fully recovered by the end of the month.

options.text: He recovered last month.
His recovery will be complete before the month finishes.
He will start recovering at the end of the month.
He is not recovering at all.

tasks.explanation: 'Will have fully recovered by the end of the month' uses Future Perfect to predict complete recovery before a deadline.

tasks.audioText: The chef is preparing a special tasting menu for tonight. He will have cooked eight different courses by the time the guests sit down.
tasks.transcript: He will have cooked eight different courses by the time the guests sit down.

options.text: He will start cooking when the guests arrive.
He cooked eight courses yesterday.
All eight courses will be ready before the guests take their seats.
The guests will cook the courses themselves.

tasks.explanation: 'Will have cooked by the time the guests sit down' uses Future Perfect to show preparation completed before a future event.
